snippet: Mr. García Márquez, who received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1982, wrote fiction rooted in a mythical Latin American landscape of his own creation.
abstract: Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Colombian novelist whose book One Hundred Years of Solitude established him as a giant of 20th-century literature, dies at age 87; Garcia Marquez received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1982; while his fiction was rooted in a mythical Latin American landscape of his own creation, its appeal was universal.

byline.contributor: Randal C. Archibold contributed reporting from Mexico City.

lead_paragraph: Mr. García Márquez, who received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1982, wrote fiction rooted in a mythical Latin American landscape of his own creation.

headline.main: Gabriel García Márquez, Conjurer of Literary Magic, Dies at 87
headline.print_headline: Gabriel García Márquez, Conjurer of Literary Magic, Dies at 87
